```{r}
library(tidyverse)
cars <- read_csv("mtcars16.csv")
```
```{r}
fit_1 <- lm(mpg ~ disp, data = cars)

plot(fit_1,1)

summary(fit_1)
```
```{r}
fit_2 <- lm(mpg ~ poly(disp, 2, raw = TRUE), data = cars)

plot(fit_2,1)

summary(fit_2)
```
```{r}
fit_3 <- lm(mpg ~ poly(disp, 3, raw = TRUE), data = cars)

plot(fit_3,1)

summary(fit_3)
```
```{r}
fit_4 <- lm(mpg ~ poly(disp, 4, raw = TRUE), data = cars)

plot(fit_4,1)

summary(fit_4)
```

Based on the model coefficients, the best model is the linear one. It has a p-value of 7.35e-9. The best model based on the residual plots is the fourth power. The best model overall is the third power model because it has the most significant coefficients.
